Author: Alexander Hamilton
Title: General Introduction
Summary: Proposing the federalist papers to address opposition to new constitution

Author: John Jay
Title: Concerning Dangers from Foreign Force and Influence

Author: John Jay
Title: The Same Subject Continued: Concerning Dangers From Foreign Force and Influence
Summary: Addresses the utility of the Union in protecting Americans against foreign aggression and meddling

Author: John Jay
Title: The Same Subject Continued: Concerning Dangers From Foreign Force and Influence
Summary: Argues that having one national government is more advantageous than having separate state governments from a military perspective

Author: John Jay
Title: The Same Subject Continued: Concerning Dangers from Foreign Force and Influence
Summary: The nation should remain united as a fractured nation of many states would repeat the mistakes of Great Britain. Equality of states is impossible and would result in envy and distrust, and states may forge alliances with foreign nations independently of others. A single nation is crucial for success.

Author: Alexander Hamilton
Title: Concerning Dangers from Dissensions Between the States
Summary: Description of potential dangers that can arise due to political dissention within a country with historic, foreign examples

Author: Alexander Hamilton
Title: The Same Subject Continued: Concerning Dangers from Dissensions Between the States
Summary: Addresses the dangers of dissension among states if there is no strong federal government; suggests the likelihood of war over peace if the unity of states is dissolved.

Author: Alexander Hamilton
Title: The Consequences of Hostilities Between the States
Summary: If individual states are not united under the Union, it will inevitably lead to war between the states, putting smaller states at the most risk. This would lead to standing armies and the rise of monarchies in order to lead these armies and protect citizens of each state, while simultaneously infringing on individual liberties. If the states unite as one country, internal wars can be avoided and liberty can be preserved.

Author: Alexander Hamilton
Title: The Union as a Safeguard Against Domestic Faction and Insurrection
Summary: The goal of the Union is to prevent domestic factions (dissenting groups) and insurrection (uprising against the government). There will be distribution of power, legislative checks and balances, courts of judges,and representation of the people in elections in order to maintain an excellent republican government. Hamilton quotes Montesquieu's philosophies in support of pointing out a union's tendency to repress domestic faction and insurrection.

Author: James Madison
Title: The Same Subject Continued: The Union as a Safeguard Against Domestic Faction and Insurrection
Summary: This federalist paper defends the structure of the republican government suggested by the constitution. He asserts that having many factions will avoid tyranny and that the large size of the nation will result in difficulty for a single faction to take control.

Author: Alexander Hamilton
Title: The Utility of the Union in Respect to Commercial Relations and a Navy
Summary: The establishment of a federal navy will protect the commercial and naval interests of the new fledging United States, and these commercial relations are the lifeline of the new economy

Author: Alexander Hamilton
Title: The Utility of the Union In Respect to Revenue
Summary: The prosperity of commerce is now perceived and acknowledged by all enlightened statesmen to be the most useful as well as the most productive source of national wealth, and has accordingly become a primary object of their political cares.

Author: Alexander Hamilton
Title: Advantage of the Union in Respect to Economy in Government

Author: James Madison
Title: Objections to the Proposed Constitution From Extent of Territory Answered

Author: Alexander Hamilton
Title: The Same Subject Continued: The Insufficiency of the Present Confederation to Preserve the Union
Summary: warns citizens that the states have reached national humiliation. There is impending anarchy between the states and borrowing and lending policies are causing turmoil. Publius says that the states must make a firm stand for their tranquility, dignity and reputation by creating a new government with a more energetic executive.

Author: Alexander Hamilton
Title: The Same Subject Continued: The Insufficiency of the Present Confederation to Preserve the Union
Summary: The tendency of the principle of legislation for States, or communities, in their political capacities, as it has been exemplified by the experiment we have made of it, is equally attested by the events which have befallen all other governments of the confederate kind, of which we have any account, in exact proportion to its prevalence in those systems.

Author: Alexander Hamilton
Title: The Same Subject Continued: The Insufficiency of the Present Confederation to Preserve the Union
Summary: Addresses the possible encroachment by states on federal powers. Addresses the idea that state governments will have popular backing to resist any federal encroachment on states rights.

Author: Alexander Hamilton and James Madison
Title: The Same Subject Continued: The Insufficiency of the Present Confederation to Preserve the Union
Summary: Addresses the failure of the Articles of Confederation to satisfactorily govern the United States.

Author: Alexander Hamilton and James Madison
Title: The Insufficiency of the Present Confederation to Preserve the Union

Author: Alexander Hamilton and James Madison
Title: The Same Subject Continued: The Insufficiency of the Present Confederation to Preserve the Union
Summary: Regards how the States-General of unions have high powers and responsibilities, and these deputies should be treating the provinces in unanimity. Especially because it's these provinces who appoint these deputies.

Author: Alexander Hamilton
Title: Other Defects of the Present Confederation
Summary: The federal government can defend each of the states individually and access taxes directly.

Author: Alexander Hamilton
Title: The Same Subject Continued: Other Defects of the Present Confederation
Summary: The power to regulate commerce is one of the strongest reasons to switch from the Articles of Confederation to a stronger "federal superintendence". Current structure under the confederation is weak and unable to support the demands that are required of a global nation

Author: Alexander Hamilton
Title: The Necessity of a Government as Energetic as the One Proposed to the Preservation of the Union
Summary: The necessity of a Constitution, at least equally energetic with the one proposed, to the preservation of the Union, is the point at the examination of which we are now arrived.

Author: Alexander Hamilton
Title: The Powers Necessary to the Common Defense Further Considered

Author: Alexander Hamilton
Title: The Same Subject Continued: The Powers Necessary to the Common Defense Further Considered
Summary: There is a great importance for a Union-backed military that can protect all the States in the case where foreign nations attack. The States themselves should make it a priority to provide for the forces as well.

Author: Alexander Hamilton
Title: The Idea of Restraining the Legislative Authority in Regard to the Common Defense Considered
Summary: It is ineffective to prohibit standing armies. Restricting the size of a standing army makes sense, but disallowing them altogether does not make sense.

Author: Alexander Hamilton
Title: The Same Subject Continued: The Idea of Restraining the Legislative Authority in Regard to the Common Defense Considered

Author: Alexander Hamilton
Title: The Same Subject Continued: The Idea of Restraining the Legislative Authority in Regard to the Common Defense Considered

Author: Alexander Hamilton
Title: Concerning the Militia
Summary: A well-regulated (efficient) militia composed of the people will be more uniform and beneficial to the "public defense" of Americans. An excessively large militia can harm a nation's work force, as not everyone can leave their profession to go through military exercises. Thus, a smaller, but still well-regulated militia, is the answer. The militia, as it is constituted directly of the people and managed by the states, is not a danger to liberty when called into use by other states to do things such as quell insurrections.

Author: Alexander Hamilton
Title: Concerning the General Power of Taxation
Summary: The federal government should adopt a policy of taxation that applies to all citizens of the United States.

Author: Alexander Hamilton
Title: The Same Subject Continued: Concerning the General Power of Taxation
Summary: A government must possess all the powers necessary for achieving its objectives, including taxation, which will be limited by the body of elected representatives.

Author: Alexander Hamilton
Title: The Same Subject Continued: Concerning the General Power of Taxation
Summary: Hamilton acknowledges that the concurrent power of taxation could lead to situations in which state governments and the national government impose taxes on the same item, but the prudence of governments can be relied on to avoid such situations

Author: Alexander Hamilton
Title: The Same Subject Continued: Concerning the General Power of Taxation
Summary: power to lay and collect taxes must be a power to pass all laws NECESSARY and PROPER for the execution of that power

Author: Alexander Hamilton
Title: The Same Subject Continued: Concerning the General Power of Taxation
Summary: Taxes are necessary to support wars, which are necessary to defend the state

Author: Alexander Hamilton
Title: The Same Subject Continued: Concerning the General Power of Taxation
Summary: The oppression of particular branches of industry; and an unequal distribution of the taxes, as well among the several States as among the citizens of the same State

Author: Alexander Hamilton
Title: The Same Subject Continued: Concerning the General Power of Taxation
Summary: Hamilton details the government's need for a body of tax collectors knowledgeable of every district, so as to establish a value to be taxed. He claims that this will be accomplished by using the same tax collectors as the state governments do. Hamilton argues against a poll tax

Author: James Madison
Title: Concerning the Difficulties of the Convention in Devising a Proper Form of Government

Author: James Madison
Title: The Same Subject Continued, and the Incoherence of the Objections to the New Plan Exposed
Summary: Criticizing those who oppose the creation of the new Constitution.

Author: James Madison
Title: The Conformity of the Plan to Republican Principles
Summary: Talks about what a nation is and where the power of the government comes from. Discusses the nature of power in relation to authority.

Author: James Madison
Title: The Powers of the Convention to Form a Mixed Government Examined and Sustained
Summary: This paper discusses the authority of the convention to create the constitution.

Author: James Madison
Title: General View of the Powers Conferred by the Constitution

Author: James Madison
Title: The Powers Conferred by the Constitution Further Considered
Summary: A description of the general government, its functionalities, duties and obligations as the second class of power.

Author: James Madison
Title: The Same Subject Continued: The Powers Conferred by the Constitution Further Considered
Summary: Madison discusses “miscellaneous powers” such as the power of patents and copyright, laws for the capital city and federal buildings, treason punishment, and the power to admit new states to the union. The national government cannot join or separate states without consent of the states themselves.

Author: James Madison
Title: Restrictions on the Authority of the Several States
Summary: States rights vs. federal rights

Author: James Madison
Title: The Alleged Danger From the Powers of the Union to the State Governments Considered
Summary: The powers granted to the national government by the Constitution do not threaten the powers left to the states. State governments will lose some of their importance and sovereignty as a result of the Constitution.

Author: James Madison
Title: The Influence of the State and Federal Governments Compared

Author: James Madison
Title: The Particular Structure of the New Government and the Distribution of Power Among Its Different Parts

Author: James Madison
Title: These Departments Should Not Be So Far Separated as to Have No Constitutional Control Over Each Other
Summary: Only setting constitutional limits on governmental departments is insufficient. These departments should have constitutional control over each other

Author: Alexander Hamilton or James Madison
Title: Method of Guarding Against the Encroachments of Any One Department of Government by Appealing to the People Through a Convention
Summary: The author begins by agreeing that there is logic to the idea of allowing the people to appeal through the use of a convention, but then explains that it would be unworkable and contradictory to the proposed Constitution.

Author: Alexander Hamilton or James Madison
Title: Periodic Appeals to the People Considered
Summary: Advocating periodical appeals to determine if the constitution has been violated in order to better enforce it

Author: Alexander Hamilton or James Madison
Title: The Structure of the Government Must Furnish the Proper Checks and Balances Between the Different Departments
Summary: Arguments and reasoning behind American government structure and division of pwoer between the legislative, judicial and executive branches for better functioning of the government.

Author: Alexander Hamilton or James Madison
Title: The House of Representatives
Summary: On the electors of the House of Representatives and electors of State governments

Author: Alexander Hamilton or James Madison
Title: The Same Subject Continued: The House of Representatives

Author: Alexander Hamilton or James Madison
Title: The Apportionment of Members Among the States
Summary: How to appoint members of the House of Representatives. On what basis to appoint members.

Author: Alexander Hamilton or James Madison
Title: The Total Number of the House of Representatives
Summary: Argues for ideal number of people in the House of Representatives in order to have a successful, representative, and democratic government and that a smaller number is harmful.

Author: Alexander Hamilton or James Madison
Title: The Same Subject Continued: The Total Number of the House of Representatives
Summary: The number of people in the House of Representatives and how many people are responsible for electing how many representatives (?)

Author: Alexander Hamilton or James Madison
Title: The Alleged Tendency of the Plan to Elevate the Few at the Expense of the Many Considered in Connection with Representation

Author: Madison
Title: Objection that the Number of Members Will Not Be Augmented as the Progress of Population Demands Considered
Summary: Federalist No. 58 is an essay by James Madison, the fifty-eighth of The Federalist Papers. This paper examines the ability of the United States House of Representatives to grow with the population of the United States.

Author: Alexander Hamiliton
Title: Concerning the Power of Congress to Regulate the Election of Members

Author: Alexander Hamilton
Title: The Same Subject Continued: Concerning the Power of Congress to Regulate the Election of Members

Author: Alexander Hamilton
Title: The Same Subject Continued: Concerning the Power of Congress to Regulate the Election of Members
Summary: Argued for Congress setting a uniform time for elections to be held and the innecessity of requiring elections to be held in the counties where the electors reside

Author: Alexander Hamilton or James Madison
Title: The Senate
Summary: Details and seeks to justify the organization of the United States Senate

Author: Alexander Hamilton or James Madison
Title: The Senate Continued
Summary: Continuation of arguments to justify the organization of the U.S. Senate

Author: John Jay
Title: The Powers of the Senate
Summary: Treaties and how they are formed under the constiution

Author: Alexander Hamilton
Title: The Powers of the Senate Continued

Author: Alexander Hamilton
Title: Objections to the Power of the Senate To Set as a Court for Impeachments Further Considered
Summary: Hamilton responds to four objections that were raised against the Senate’s right to be a court for an impeachment trial.

Author: Alexander Hamilton
Title: The Executive Department
Summary: Analyzes certain parts of constitutions to point out that presidents are not allowed to fill in vacancies in senate

Author: Hamilton
Title: The Mode of Electing the President

Author: Alexander Hamilton
Title: The Real Character of the Executive
Summary: Outlines the checks and balances on the office of the president of the United States and deliberately highlights the differences between the US President and the king of England.

Author: Alexander Hamilton
Title: The Executive Department Further Considered

Author: Alexander Hamilton
Title: The Duration in Office of the Executive
Summary: How long the presidential term of office should be.

Author: Alexander Hamilton
Title: The Same Subject Continued, and Re-Eligibility of the Executive Considered
Summary: A continuation of the previous argument regarding the duration of the executive role, and a discussion of presedential re-eligibility

Author: Alexander Hamilton
Title: The Provision For The Support of the Executive, and the Veto Power
The Command of the Military and Naval Forces, and the Pardoning Power of the Executive

Author: Alexander Hamilton
Title: The Treaty Making Power of the Executive
Summary: discusses why the treaty making power should not be solely entrusted in a single branch of the government.

Author: Alexander Hamilton
Title: The Appointing Power of the Executive
Summary: role of president in nominating Supreme Court Justices and other roles

Title: The Appointing Power Continued and Other Powers of the Executive Considered
Summary: the constitutional provisions for the presidency have successfully incorporated “all the requisites of energy” without violating republican principles of liberty

Title: The Judiciary Department

Author: Alexander Hamilton
Title: The Judiciary Continued
The Powers of the Judiciary

Author: Alexander Hamilton
Title: The Judiciary Continued, and the Distribution of Judicial Authority
Summary: The Supreme Court and subsidary state/district courts of the United States will work collectively to ensure equal and just laws.

Author: Alexander Hamilton
Title: The Judiciary Continued
Summary: Establishes that the judicual power rests solely on the supreme court.

Title: The Judiciary Continued in Relation to Trial by Jury
Certain General and Miscellaneous Objections to the Constitution Considered and Answered

Author: Alexander Hamilton
Title: Concluding Remarks
